text: Hey all! I’m back with video marketing questions :sweat_smile: we’re going to be adding video embeds to some of our highest performing blog posts (the ones getting the most visits these past few weeks). I want to figure out a way to measure the *engagement* success of adding videos to a blog post. I’m measuring *bounce rate*, *average visit duration*, *# of pages per visit,* but I’m curious to learn what other metrics folks have used to determine if it’s worth it to include video embeds in blog content. Thanks

text:
Hi all,

My company launched a blog before I started on <https://blog.scribehow.com/|Ghost on a subdomain>.

We're moving to webflow and to a subfolder (<http://scribehow.com/blog|scribehow.com/blog>).

Anyone know the best process or can direct me to a resource for this process?

attachments.text: Learnings and lessons on entrepreneurship, productivity, procedural knowledge, and all things process.
attachments.title: Scribe Blog

text:
Hey Vanessa! We’re going through the exact same process right now actually (embedding videos to blog posts).

I’m thinking right now context is most important. For example, we’re creating a video on “what is user onboarding?” We’ll embed that into blog posts that has that section.

If I’m not mistake, that’s the exact same thing Sam Oh did at Ahrefs

elements.text:

text: Hey Ramli! you’re right--that’s how they discussed part of their video marketing strategy.

elements.text: Hey Ramli! you’re right--that’s how they discussed part of their video marketing strategy.

text:
1. Migrate blogs to Webflow, keep in draft until you're ready for step 3. If you're asking specifically about importing blogs to Webflow, I can't be much help :slightly_smiling_face: 
2. Publish Webflow blogs.
3. Create a 301 redirect from the subdomain to the main domain. You can either:
    a. Redirect <http://blog.scribehow.com|blog.scribehow.com> -> <http://scribehow.com|scribehow.com> and then handle each blog's  page-level 301 redirect individually in Webflow (under the "Hosting" tab); or
    b. You could probably do some sort of redirect re-write rule like this <http://blog.scribehow.com/[post-url]|blog.scribehow.com/[post-url]> -> <http://scribehow.com/blog/[post-url]|scribehow.com/blog/[post-url]>. That's probably easier, but I'm not an expert on the technical side here.

elements.text: Migrate blogs to Webflow, keep in draft until you're ready for step 3. If you're asking specifically about importing blogs to Webflow, I can't be much help
Publish Webflow blogs.
Create a 301 redirect from the subdomain to the main domain. You can either:
Redirect
blog.scribehow.com
scribehow.com
and then handle each blog's  page-level 301 redirect individually in Webflow (under the "Hosting" tab); or
You could probably do some sort of redirect re-write rule like this
blog.scribehow.com/[post-url]
scribehow.com/blog/[post-url]
. That's probably easier, but I'm not an expert on the technical side here.

text: Thank you!

elements.text: Thank you!

text: I've done a bunch of blog migrations like this. You may see a little organic volatility in the first few weeks but it tends to level out and then climb steadily if you have better DA.

elements.text: I've done a bunch of blog migrations like this. You may see a little organic volatility in the first few weeks but it tends to level out and then climb steadily if you have better DA.

text:
Luckily there's very little organic to lose! Annoying it was so little content published on the subdomain before I started.

But there are just enough good links to our funding announcement it's worth salvaging

text:
Hello everyone! I'm looking to run some content audits for our blog in multiple sprints:
1. Sprint one will focus on the quality and efficacy of each blog post based on engagement metrics, such as clicks to our demo page, downloadables, case studies, and product pages, as well as conversion metrics, such as MQLs generated. I want to focus all my attention on having high-quality content that _actually_ moves people through the funnel before working on SEO. 
2. The Second sprint will be an on-page SEO audit.
3. The third sprint will be the technical SEO audit. We have about 1,000 blog posts. 
I've found some good tools and resources for 2 & 3 but nothing for #1 /: Google Analytics would be far too manual for the number of posts we have, at least based on what I've tried. Anyone have any tools, templates, advice, etc. to help me automate this, or just general advice? Please :tired_face: and thank you!

elements.text: Hello everyone! I'm looking to run some content audits for our blog in multiple sprints:

Sprint one will focus on the quality and efficacy of each blog post based on engagement metrics, such as clicks to our demo page, downloadables, case studies, and product pages, as well as conversion metrics, such as MQLs generated. I want to focus all my attention on having high-quality content that
actually
moves people through the funnel before working on SEO.
The Second sprint will be an on-page SEO audit.
The third sprint will be the technical SEO audit. We have about 1,000 blog posts.

I've found some good tools and resources for 2 & 3 but nothing for #1 /: Google Analytics would be far too manual for the number of posts we have, at least based on what I've tried. Anyone have any tools, templates, advice, etc. to help me automate this, or just general advice? Please
and thank you!

<https://www.analyticsmania.com/post/google-tag-manager-video-tracking/>
